channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.
channel.dc:rights: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Pakistan stars 'unlikely' to play
item.description: The Pakistan cricketers under scrutiny for claims of spot-fixing are unlikely to play again on the current England tour, BBC Sport understands.

item.title: Iraq PM hails US troop withdrawal
item.description: Iraq's prime minister says the country is now "independent", hours before US combat operations are due to end officially.

item.title: Miliband battle 'like soap opera'
item.description: Labour leadership candidate Ed Balls criticises the "daily episodes" of the "soap opera" surrounding fellow contenders Ed and David Miliband.

item.title: Four-year negative equity warning
item.description: The National Housing Federation warns that homeowners in England who bought at the peak may face four more years of negative equity.

item.title: Work begins on Chile rescue shaft
item.description: Engineers in Chile begin drilling a rescue shaft to reach the 33 men trapped in a collapsed mine.

item.title: Afghan attacks kill US soldiers
item.description: Five American soldiers are killed in three separate bomb attacks in Afghanistan, Nato says.

item.title: 'Rogue trader' given prison term
item.description: A locksmith who carried out unnecessary work and overcharged vulnerable customers is jailed for four years.

item.title: Teenagers die in car lake plunge
item.description: Two teenagers die and three other young people escape after a car plunges down an embankment into a lake in Ceredigion.

item.title: Dutch police quiz US flight pair
item.description: Dutch police question two men arriving from Chicago, after the US authorities alerted them to suspicious items in their luggage.

item.title: Ryanair pulls out of Belfast City
item.description: Ryanair is ceasing services from Belfast City Airport from 31 October, the airline has announced.

item.title: 'Brisk walks' to prevent cancers
item.description: About 10,000 cases of breast and bowel cancer could be prevented each year in the UK if people did more brisk walking, claim experts.

item.title: Author JK Rowling gives £10m for MS centre
item.description: Author JK Rowling donates £10m to set up a multiple sclerosis research centre at Edinburgh University.

item.title: Fossils from new type of dinosaur found in Romania
item.description: Fossils of a new type of dinosaur, which looks like a beefy version of the predatory Velociraptor, have been unearthed in Romania.

item.title: Live - Transfer deadline day
item.description: Clubs are trying to push through some final deals before the summer transfer window slams shut at 1800 BST on Tuesday.

item.title: Federer strolls into second round
item.description: Five-time champion Roger Federer gets his US Open campaign off to a smooth start as he defeats Argentina's Brian Dabul in straight sets.

item.title: Tour legend Fignon dies aged 50
item.description: Two-time Tour de France winner Laurent Fignon dies of cancer at the age of 50.

item.title: FA seeks to avoid Cup final clash
item.description: The Football Association is in talks with the Premier League to avoid a fixture clash as the FA Cup final will be played on a regular league Saturday next May.

item.title: England hindered by injury doubts
item.description: England's preparations for Friday's Euro 2012 qualifier against Bulgaria have been hit by a series of injuries.

item.title: Wanted kick boxer held by police
item.description: A kick boxer from Birmingham wanted over the murder of a US marine is arrested at London's Heathrow Airport.

item.title: Coast search resumes for kayaker
item.description: A search resumes for a 53-year-old kayaker who has been missing off Anglesey since Sunday afternoon.

item.title: Report calls for drink price curb
item.description: A UK-wide "floor price" for alcohol should be established to reduce consumption, says a commission set up by Scottish Labour.

item.title: Gang jailed for £3m cannabis haul
item.description: Four men involved in one of Scotland's biggest illegal drug operations are jailed after being caught with £3m of cannabis resin.

item.title: Westlink bomb alert declared hoax
item.description: A security alert which closed the busy Westlink road in Belfast ends and is declared a hoax.

item.title: Boy struck by boat critically ill
item.description: A six-year-old boy remains in a critical condition after he was hit by a boat on Monday afternoon.

item.title: First S4C chief Owen Edwards dies
item.description: The first chief executive of Welsh language channel S4C and former BBC Wales controller Owen Edwards has died aged 76.

item.title: Lotto £117,944 win goes unclaimed
item.description: A National Lottery ticket holder misses out on £117,944 after failing to claim the prize, and the money goes to charity.

item.title: South Africa wage offer increased
item.description: South Africa's government increases its wage offer to more than a million striking public sector workers, but it is below the union's demand.

item.title: Gaddafi in 'black Europe' warning
item.description: Libya's Col Gaddafi says the EU should pay Libya at least 5bn euros a year to stop illegal African immigration and avoid a "black Europe".

item.title: South Korea offers aid to North
item.description: South Korea makes its first offer of aid to flood-hit North Korea since it accused Pyongyang of sinking a South Korean warship in March.

item.title: Chinese court to tackle HIV case
item.description: A Chinese court for the first time accepts a case from a man alleging employment discrimination because he has HIV, state media says.

item.title: Anglo Irish Bank in £6.4bn loss
item.description: Nationalised lender Anglo Irish Bank has announced the largest corporate loss in the history of the Republic of Ireland.

item.title: Seven killed by Bratislava gunman
item.description: A gunman opens fire in Slovakia's capital, Bratislava, shooting dead seven people and injuring at least 14 before killing himself, police say.

item.title: Mexico arrests 'drug lord' Valdez
item.description: Mexican police detain alleged drug trafficker Edgar "Barbie" Valdez, wanted in the US on cocaine charges, the attorney general says.

item.title: Anti-Chavez hunger striker dies
item.description: A Venezuelan farmer who campaigned against the land-redistribution policies of Hugo Chavez dies after five months on hunger strike.

item.title: Iran paper calls Bruni prostitute
item.description: An Iranian newspaper calls France's first lady Carla Bruni a "prostitute" after she condemns Iran's plan to stone a woman to death.

item.title: Rabbi calls for Abbas to 'vanish'
item.description: An Israeli rabbi says the world would be better without Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas, prompting strong criticism from US officials.

item.title: Google and Skype face India ban
item.description: Following tough action against Blackberry, security forces in India turn their attention to Google and Skype.

item.title: India growth rate rises to 8.8%
item.description: India's economy grows at its fastest rate for more than two years in the last quarter, according to official data.

item.title: Hurricane hits eastern Caribbean
item.description: Hurricane Earl strengthens to a category-four storm, causing power outages and dumping heavy rain across the eastern Caribbean.

item.title: Corpse of long-lost climber found
item.description: Hikers in Canada discover the frozen body of an American ice climber who fell to his death more than two decades ago.

item.title: Pensions 'require funding boost'
item.description: Workers may need to pay more for their pensions amid a continuing picture of fund deficits, two surveys suggest.

item.title: Eurozone joblessness still at 10%
item.description: Unemployment in the eurozone remained at a record rate of 10% for a fifth month in a row, according to official figures.

item.title: Japan Airlines slashes workforce
item.description: Japan Airlines, which entered bankruptcy protection this year, announces plans to cut 16,000 staff and 40% of its aircraft.

item.title: Private toll roads 'no solution'
item.description: Private toll roads are not a cost-effective answer to traffic problems, the government is warned by transport campaigners.

item.title: Burnham: I can win Labour contest
item.description: Labour leadership candidate Andy Burnham has dismissed suggestions that it is a "two-horse race" between David and Ed Miliband.

item.title: By-laws to be easier to abolish
item.description: Plans to make it easier for English local authorities to abolish outdated by-laws and create new ones will be outlined later by the government.

item.title: Burnham presses Lib Dems on NHS
item.description: Shadow health secretary Andy Burnham is urging Lib Dems to unite with Labour against the Government's plan for a radical overhaul of the NHS.

item.title: Baby died after superbug hit ward
item.description: A baby died and three others became ill after a superbug resistant to common antibiotics hit a London hospital, it is revealed.

item.title: Pill may 'cut heart failure rate'
item.description: A pill costing less than £1.50 a day has the potential to save the lives of thousands of heart failure patients, research suggests.

item.title: After-school clubs 'too costly'
item.description: Nearly two-thirds of UK parents cannot afford after-school activities for their children, a poll for the Save the Children charity suggests.

item.title: Half of all private pupils get As
item.description: Half the A-levels taken by pupils at independent schools in the UK were graded A or A* this year, figures from the sector suggest.

item.title: Watchdog vets alternative exams
item.description: England's exams watchdog Ofqual is to compare A-levels and GCSEs with alternative qualifications, including vocational equivalents.

item.title: Google to relieve e-mail overload
item.description: Google launches priority inbox to help conquer email overload and rank messages that matter most.

item.title: Intel to buy German wireless unit
item.description: US chipmaker Intel agrees to buy the wireless unit of German counterpart Infineon for $1.4bn, disappointing markets.

item.title: Billionaire sues hi-tech giants
item.description: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen is suing several high-tech giants for infringing patents held by a Silicon Valley lab he founded in the 1990s.

item.title: Stricter checks for climate body
item.description: The UN's climate science body needs stricter checks to prevent damage to its credibility, an independent review concludes.

item.title: Geneticists crack apple genome
item.description: A team of 86 global scientists sequence the genetic code of the Golden Delicious apple for the first time.

item.title: Double strike 'killed dinosaurs'
item.description: The dinosaurs were wiped out by at least two space impacts rather than a single strike, say scientists.

item.title: Mad Men wins third top Emmy prize
item.description: Hit US series Mad Men takes its third award Emmy for best drama series, while British stars face disappointment in Los Angeles.

item.title: Norton replacing Friday with Ross
item.description: Graham Norton's chat show is to replace Friday Night with Jonathan Ross, the controller of BBC One has said.

item.title: Cinema attendance is down in US
item.description: Box office receipts in the US were up by $100m (£64.9m) this summer, despite the lowest attendance in five years, figures show.

item.title: How the Guides knitted and dug for victory
item.description: Girl Guiding during the Second World War was vital to the survival of the country and the international war effort.

item.title: How we construct our reputations
item.description: While engineers can be judged almost instantly by their work, a longer-term view is required for politicians, says Lisa Jardine.

item.title: Why has studying French lost its élan?
item.description: Is the big fall in the number of British school children studying French something to be concerned about?

item.title: Hurricane Earl heading for US coast
item.description: Hurricane Earl is expected to gain more strength before heading towards the US

item.title: Can toll roads solve traffic congestion?
item.description: Toll roads are not the economical answer to traffic problems, according to a new report.

item.title: Cairo zoo puts lions on the pill
item.description: Vets at Cairo's Giza Zoo are experimenting with the human birth control pill in an attempt to slow their rapidly expanding population of lions.

item.title: Iraq base for 'forgotten' US troops
item.description: The US troops who are staying behind in Iraq talk about their new role in the country

item.title: Pakistan faces debris and ruin
item.description: Emergency workers in Pakistan say flood waters in some parts of the country have started to recede, one month since torrential rain caused catastrophic flooding across Pakistan

item.title: 'Spiderman' climbs again in Sydney
item.description: A French climber, known as 'Spiderman', is facing charges after scaling a 57-storey building in Australia.

item.title: Pakistan anger at cricket scandal
item.description: As most of Pakistan is struggling to cope with the worst floods in decades, the betting scandal surrounding some of the country's cricket team has shaken already low national morale.

item.title: Thousands flee Indonesia volcano
item.description: Thousands of Indonesians have been forced to leave their homes after a volcano erupted on the island of Sumatra.

item.title: Shrunken superpower
item.description: John Simpson on the legacy of America's 'imperial moment'

item.title: Journey planner
item.description: How do you sum up a life story in two words?

item.title: Who are 4chan?
item.description: The internet pranksters who helped expose cat bin lady

item.title: Inside job
item.description: How much is real policing like it is on The Bill?

item.title: In the beginning...
item.description: Meet Google's first ever employee
